content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

Access to sustainable energy is not just a luxury; it is a fundamental enabler to human rights that underpins our ability to thrive, as highlighted in Lesson 1. However, ensuring sustainable energy access requires that energy services meet critical requirements: affordability, availability, safety, reliability, and adequacy. all linked to the sustainability of energy. When energy is out of reach or unreliable, communities suffer, opportunities are lost, and progress stalls. In contrast, when these requirements are met, energy can drive multiple facets of development. In Lesson 2, you will gain insight into the building blocks of sustainable energy access and explore the various development outcomes it can support.

concepts.title: sustainable energy access
concepts.body: Sustainable energy access refers to the ability of all individuals and communities to obtain reliable, affordable, and clean energy sources that meet their needs without compromising the environment or future generations.

content.title: Part 1: Building blocks of sustainable energy

content.text: Part 1 Overview

To achieve sustainable energy access, addressing six critical requirements—affordability, availability, safety, reliability, adequacy, and low carbon compatibility—is essential. These components form the foundation of effective energy systems, ensuring that all individuals and communities can access and benefit from energy services. In addition, sustainable energy must align with climate goals and health considerations by minimizing greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution. This means prioritizing low-carbon and renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, and phasing out high-emission technologies. A clear understanding of these requirements is vital for developing strategies that guarantee impactful interventions. These are detailed to follow.
Availability

Availability means having energy sources and services that people can actually use in a given area or community. This refers to energy infrastructure, including electricity grids, fuel distribution systems and renewable energy installation.
Adequacy

Adequacy refers to the ability of the energy system to meet the specific energy demands of a population or community in terms of quantity and quality, and address the multifaceted and ever-evolving needs of individuals and communities. This demands contextual consideration, including geographical and socio-cultural factors, which significantly influence how a community defines its energy requirements
Reliability

Reliability refers to the uninterrupted and predictable delivery of energy services. Energy services must be consistent, dependable and resilient to ensure that people, communities, institutions and businesses can operate efficiently. Reliable energy services are critical to guaranteeing energy availability, supporting economic activities, daily life, and promoting social development.
Affordability

Energy services must be within economic reach for individuals and communities. This includes the cost of obtaining energy as well as ongoing expenses. Affordability is a necessary condition for inclusive energy services, ensuring that basic energy needs do not impose an unsustainable strain on households, with particular attention to those in lower income brackets.
Safety

Energy sources and technologies should not compromise health or harm the environment. Energy safety involves practices, standards, and measures ensuring the safe production, distribution, and use of energy to prevent risks like fires, electrical shocks or environmental harm. It protects users, infrastructure, and ecosystems by promoting safe equipment, preventing accidents, minimizing pollution, and ensuring resilience during disruptions or emergencies in energy systems.
Low Carbon Compatibility

Energy systems must align with climate and environmental goals by minimizing greenhouse gas emissions and reducing ecological harm. This means prioritizing renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, and phasing out high-emission technologies. Environmentally sustainable energy supports long-term human and planetary health by contributing to climate change mitigation, preserving natural resources, and ensuring energy systems do not compromise ecosystems for future generations.

These six aspects - availability, reliability, affordability, safety, adequacy and low carbon compatibility - often overlap but are distinct. Together, they form the foundation of sustainable energy access and inclusive energy services. They also guide our understanding of the multifaceted nature of energy access, and shine a light on the path toward ensuring comprehensive, inclusive energy services. h

content.title: Part 2: Energy to (Em)power

content.text: Part 2 Overview

As introduced in Module 1, energy is deeply intertwined with the social and economic fabric of society. This section will focus on the transformative impact of energy access on achieving key development outcomes, including health, agriculture, and gender equality, while also exploring its broader role in empowering communities. By understanding these interconnections, we can develop integrated solutions that leverage energy to drive progress across multiple Sustainable Development Goals.

The ramifications of energy access stretch far beyond the glow of a well-lit room or the hum of a refrigerator. Energy, or the lack thereof, is intricately woven into the fabric of society and the dynamics of economies. Sustainable energy access is at the center of numerous essential services pivotal for enhancing the quality of life. Access to affordable and clean energy is intricately interlinked to multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Understanding these synergies helps to devise comprehensive and integrated energy-related actions that can strategically leverage multiple other SDGs.
Keep in mind what is most important

The mutual relationship between energy access and fundamental services such as health, education, clean water and sanitation, and decent work underscores the need for an integrated approach to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. By recognizing these interconnections, we can develop comprehensive solutions that not only provide energy access but also contribute to broader human development, supporting healthier, safer, and more sustainable communities. Remember: Everything is interconnected
Economic development

By powering industries, businesses, and essential services, energy access helps propel economic growth, productivity and poverty reduction. One significant benefit of improved energy access is the empowerment of local entrepreneurs and small businesses: Access to electricity enables individuals to establish and operate small-scale enterprises, including shops, restaurants, manufacturing workshops, and service centers. Electricity-powered machinery and equipment enhance productivity, expand business operations, and create employment opportunities within the community. Access to electricity facilitates the adoption of modern technologies and digital platforms, enabling entrepreneurs to access new markets, streamline business processes, and improve competitiveness.
Improving Agricultural Outcomes

In agriculture, energy access is a game-changer, increasing agricultural outcomes and contributing to overall economic development. See three ways that agricultural outcomes are improved by energy access: Farmers can use electric pumps for irrigation, enhancing crop yields and diversifying their agricultural activities. Cold storage powered by electricity ensures that produce remains fresh and marketable for longer periods. Post-harvest processing and value addition, such as food preservation and packaging, become possible, increasing the income generated by agricultural activities.
Mitigating Emissions Pollution

The adoption of clean lighting and clean cooking solutions, can significantly reduce indoor air pollution and therefore, also the disease burden. As a result, households experience a notable decrease in the concentration of harmful particulate matter and toxic fumes, leading to fewer respiratory problems and better lung health.
Providing Energy to Hospitals

With reliable energy access, hospitals can operate more efficiently, reducing the risk of medical emergencies due to power outages and improving patient outcomes. Hospitals, as vital hubs of healthcare delivery, depend on reliable electricity in order to: Power life-saving medical equipment and provide adequate lighting for surgeries, examinations, and patient care area. Maintain optimal temperatures of vaccines and medicines. Reliable electricity sources and well-lit environments in healthcare facilities facilitate neonatal care and safe childbirth (Rokicki et al., 2019b).
Education

Energy access directly supports education by providing extended study time and enabling digital learning opportunities. Reliable electricity allows students to study longer in the evenings with clean energy solutions like solar lamps, fostering a conducive learning environment and enhancing academic performance. Access to electricity and technology provides students with digital resources, including online platforms, e-books, and multimedia content. This broadens educational opportunities and equips them with essential skills for personal and professional development in a digital world.
Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene

Energy access is essential for delivering effective Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services, which are critical for health and well-being. Electricity powers water pumps, enabling reliable access to clean and safe water for drinking, cooking, and hygiene. It supports water treatment facilities and sanitation infrastructure, improving the quality and safety of water systems. In healthcare and school settings, energy access ensures that clean water and proper sanitation are consistently available, reducing the risk of disease and supporting healthier communities.
Advancing Gender Equality

Empowering women and girls is intrinsically linked to energy access. Electrification can alleviate women’s time poverty by either speeding up or eliminating the need for routine tasks related to unpaid housework and care work (Clark, L., 2021). With electricity in homes, women and girls can spend less time on housework and more time on their education and the pursuit of income-generating activities (The IGC, 2022). Additionally, electrification improves safety and security in homes and communities, reducing the risk of gender-based violence (Princeton University, 2021).
Community Empowerment and Participation in Decision-making

Electricity enables the establishment of community-operated facilities such as community social centers, sports venues, parks, and libraries, serving as hubs for social gatherings and educational programs. These spaces foster unity and empower residents to voice their opinions and influence local decisions on the future of their communities. Improved energy access enhances community empowerment and participation in decision-making, driving socio-economic development and overall well-being. Reliable electricity enhances communication and connectivity, enabling community members to engage in dialogue, exchange information, and collaborate on collective endeavors. Access to communication tools like television, radios and mobile phones facilitate information dissemination and strengthens participation in public consultations and advocacy efforts. Peer-to-peer energy communities, groups of energy users who generate, consume, and trade energy, enhance energy access while creating opportunities for upskilling and reskilling. As residents take part in producing, managing, and trading clean energy, they gain technical and digital skills that support local jobs and long-term project sustainability.

content.title: Case Study: Yemen

content.text: Case Study RBAS: Solar for Health
Context

The lack of reliable electricity in healthcare facilities, especially in conflict zones such as Yemen, severely impacts healthcare services and consequently, human well-being. The Yemeni civil war severely undermined the country's healthcare services. Only 46% of the facilities are partially operating or fully out of service due to several reasons, such as generators stopping due to diesel fuel shortages. Therefore, addressing energy access challenges in healthcare facilities in Yemen is critical.
UNDP's solution

UNDP's Solar for Health initiative aims to address energy shortages in health care facilities by providing sustainable energy solutions. This program has been successfully implemented in multiple countries across different regions. The Initiative grounded in the belief that access to reliable, clean energy is a critical enabler of quality healthcare, particularly in crisis-affected and underserved areas like Yemen. Its theory of change centers on improving health outcomes and strengthening resilience by electrifying health facilities with solar power. The approach includes the procurement and installation of solar photovoltaic systems tailored to the energy needs of different tiers of health facilities. Solar for Health promotes community engagement through volunteer committees for system upkeep and supports policy frameworks that enable the long-term scaling of clean energy in health systems. Its financial model ensures long-term sustainability through coordinated, blended financing, bringing together governments, donors, energy service providers (ESP), and development finance institutions (DFI) to align efforts and avoid fragmented investments. Public-private partnerships enable ESPs to access DFI financing, supported by mechanisms like donor-backed payments and credit guarantees to reduce financial risk, while power purchase agreements (PPAs) between governments and ESPs provide stable revenue streams. Since 2017, this initiative has brought several beneficial outcomes to Yemeni communities: 27 healthcare facilities across Yemen have been provided with solar micro-grids and solar-power refrigerators, bringing positive impacts to 208,000 people and enabling vaccination to almost 70 children. In Al-Za’zea catchment area, the medical services provide care for over 5,000 people and increases the number of patients the healthcare facility can receive, including up to 175 visits per month by local women looking for family planning services, pregnancy care, and treatment for malnourished children. Not only does the initiative benefit the communities by providing access to electricity, it also provides dozens of workers with new skills and qualifications in sustainable energy technologies jobs.
Conclusion

The Solar for Health initiative in Yemen has resulted in positive impacts in Yemen by improving healthcare services and promoting sustainable development, including the creation of green job opportunities and skills development.
(Optional) Learn more about UNDP's Solar for Health Initiative

As the Solar for Health initiative has been implemented in multiple countries across Africa and the Arab States, it has been proven to successfully bring positive impacts to developing countries. UNDP has also supported the assessment of innovative financing mechanisms to scale this program in Malawi, Zimbabwe, Liberia, Namibia, and Zambia. The coordination platform financing model is scalable across geographies with specific features that can be tailored to local specificities. The platform can harmonize stakeholders’ interventions, such as UN agencies, donors, DFIs, private sector, and government entities, across countries in linking energy and health sectors. Furthermore, the financial model behind Solar for Health is designed to ensure the long-term financial and operational sustainability of solar installations through a coordinated approach. The Solar for Health Coordination Platform aligns donors, governments, private energy service providers (ESPs), and development finance institutions (DFIs) to avoid fragmentation and inefficiencies. To attract private investment and scale impact, the model aggregates projects into investment portfolios with appropriate risk-return profiles, enabling ESPs to access DFI funding through public-private partnerships (PPPs). These partnerships are structured to ensure predictable cash flows—supported by donor contributions and guarantees—which help reduce financial risks. Technical assistance mechanisms complement the financing model by building the capacity of local stakeholders and structuring power purchase agreements (PPAs). This integrated financing approach reduces upfront costs for governments while ensuring long-term service delivery, energy reliability, and resilience across the health sector. See more: - UNDP's Sustainable Energy Hub website - Solar for Health - UNDP, 2020. Solar for Health (S4H) Innovative Financing Feasibility Study in Liberia, Malawi, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe

These examples merely scratch the surface of opportunities energy access can bring. It's important to recognize that communities, particularly agricultural ones, have specific energy requirements related to their activities, which may starkly contrast with those of urban informal settlements, for instance. It is imperative to establish mechanisms for a comprehensive understanding of each context and associated tailored policy response, acknowledging its unique characteristics and idiosyncrasies. By adopting this nuanced approach, we can ensure that energy solutions are finely tuned to the diverse needs of different communities, fostering inclusive development that genuinely resonates with the people it serves. Overall, improved energy access is essential for fostering inclusive and sustainable development, empowering communities to shape their futures and build resilient societies.

content.title: Part 3: How is energy access measured?

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Energy drives development, but sustainable energy remains a complex and ever-evolving challenge. Understanding and effectively measuring energy access across the world is crucial for developing targeted strategies and policies that are essential to achieving universal energy access. In this section, we explore key approaches and measurement tools used to assess the global energy access landscape and track progress made so far.
ENERGY ACCESS indexes & tracking reports
The Global Tracking Framework (GTF)

The GTF was established to track progress towards achieving SDG7 using a standardized methodology for measuring and reporting on various aspects of energy access, focusing on SDG7's 4 main indicators: electricity access, clean cooking access, energy efficiency, and renewable energy adoption. The framework was developed jointly in 2013 by the International Energy Agency (IEA), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), the World Bank, and the World Health Organization (WHO) and funded by Energy System Management and Assistance Programme (ESMAP). - See the most recent reports and previous data here: Official SDG 7 Tracking Website
ENERGY ACCESS indexes & tracking reports
World Energy Outlook - Energy Access

The World Energy Outlook published annually by the International Energy Agency (IEA) provides in-depth analysis and strategic insights into data on global energy demand and supply, including implications for energy security, emissions and energy access. The latest edition of the report, published in 2024, examines the energy security challenges faced by decision-makers during the clean energy transition. To enhance its usability, WEO 2024 GPT was developed as an AI-powered tool that streamlines access to insights and data from the report. The 2022 WEO version features a video focused on energy access.
ENERGY ACCESS indexes & tracking reports
The Multi-TIER Framework

The Multi-Tier Framework (MTF) measures energy access beyond binary indicators (access/no access) by assessing the quality, reliability, affordability, and sustainability of energy services. While MTF is not an index to track progress, it is an important method to assess energy access needs for socio-economic development
OnStove Tool

Open-source clean cooking geospatial models such as the OnStove Tool deployed in Nepal, integrate cost-benefit analysis to determine the most beneficial fuel-stove alternative for communities (WRI, 2023).
The Energy Access Explorer

The Energy Access Explorer is an open-source, online geospatial platform designed for energy planners, clean energy entrepreneurs, donors, and development institutions. It helps users identify priority areas for energy access interventions. It also serves as an information system that streamlines data management and governance while reducing costs for both data providers and users (see screenshot below).

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: To be an effective proponent of universal energy access, it is essential to understand the core components of sustainable energy. This means ensuring that new services are not only available but also inclusive, reliable, affordable, safe, and adequate, so communities can fully benefit.

Energy acts as a catalyst for development across sectors like health, education, and agriculture. Integrated approaches—aligning energy initiatives with broader development goals—are essential to maximizing its impact and fully promoting prosperity.

Assessing and understanding global energy service availability is crucial for developing targeted strategies and policies. Multidimensional metrics, such as the Multi-Tier Framework, are powerful tools for accurately assessing all dimensions of sustainable energy access.
